Good afternoon, if you’d like to view these slides on your own laptop you can go to the address at the bottom of these slides and view them and I’d recommend doing so there are lots of links in the slides that may be useful. If you decide to register with OSC Sheffield you can do so at the address on the bottom left but please make sure you select OSC Sheffield under the Which OSC? field when registering.
Hi, my name is Neil Shephard, and I’m a Research Software Engineer in the Research Software Engineering Team within the Computer Science Department. I’m not hear today to talk to you about software, but about Open Scholarship Community or OSC in Sheffield.
I completed both undergraduate and post-graduate degrees here in Sheffield. I’ve worked as a Genetics Statistician at University of Manchester, Western Australia and went full circle coming back to University of Sheffield. I then spent the best part of a decade working as a Medical Statistician in the Clinical Trials Unit within ScHARR. I had a few years working in industry before returning to University of Sheffield last year to my current role as Research Software Engineer.
Early in my time at Manchester I developed an interest in reproducibility as I quickly tired of re-creating tables and copying and pasting figures into documents for internal reports and publications and taught myself literate programming with LaTeX and in time other systems. When I switched to using R for medical statistics I also learnt how to use Git to version control my code.
Despite being co-author on a number of papers that are Open Access during my time working as a Medical Statistician the code that underpinned the research was never formally published and all of the papers were authored in Word.
I think its great to see the changes since then and the increasing prominence and importance of Open Research practices as they underpin the validity of research.
I’m passionate about open research as it is fundamental and underpins the enquiry process, but I came to be here stood in front of you almost by accident. I was asked to grow the the RSE community in Sheffield and came aross the INOSC Incubator Programme which sounded like a really good way to learn about how to grow communities. But it had a specific purpose which I hadn’t clocked from the title which was to incubate a community and as a consequence I’m now stood in front of you today to tell you a bit about what I’ve learned and invite you to join the Open Scholarship Community Sheffield.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
section: International Network of Open Science Communities (INOSC)
text:
International Network of Open Science Communities (INOSC)






 


Open Science Communities are part of the International Network of Open Science Communities, which started in the Netherlands at Utrecht University but grew organically, spreading to other universities within the Netherlands who came together under the umbrella of OSC NL but it has grown beyond just one country and there are now local branches in other countries such as Eire, Saudi Arabia, Sweden and Lisbon.
They’re keen to grow the network further and with that in mind the OSC Incubator Programme was born to help seed communities in University and research institutes around the world. I had been asked to look into growing the RSE community within Sheffield when earlier this year I saw the OSC Incubator Programme was running and decided to sign up.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
OSC Incubator Programme


Nurture and grow Open Science/Scholarship Communities around the world.
Help others establish communities.
Share resources, ideas and experience.


The stated the aim is to seed, nurture and help grow Open Science/Scholarship Communities around the world by helping other researchers to establish local communities and share their resources, ideas and experiences.
There were nine participants in this cohort of the OSC Incubator Programme including myself with researchers from Greece, Portugal, France and Germany as well as Durham in the UK and its been great working being guided through the course by Loek and Anita who you will hear from later and working with the other participants to understand what is involved about establishing and growing an Open Scholarship Community.



Syllabus v1.2

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Why Communities?



But Why Communities? We all know that open science is a good thing and funders are increasingly stipulating that the output they fund should be open. This is a diagram from an article by Brian Nosek, one of the co-founders of the Center for Open Science and represents how to bring about culture and behaviour change.
Infrastructure is at the base of the pyramid of culture and behaviour change and there are systems in place such as the Open Science Framework and Octopus which is being developed by JISC. Both of which allow (or will) researchers to register their studies, share materials and data (optionally protecting sensitive data) and share outcomes at any point in the study to accelerate communication regardless of publication status.
The user interface and experience of using these tools needs to be low friction to encourage adoption and many popular services such as GitHub and Docker are integrated.
From the top of the pyramid is policy, which you are all involved in and incentives which address the reward system and these are changing towards incentivising open research practices.
But we’re not there yet as these practices are not the norm within many places and it is communities that help bridge or fill this gap. Because when people see others undertaking and engaging with open research practices in a visible manner it helps accelerate adoption.


Nosek (2019) Strategy for Culture Change

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
What are Communities?

“a dynamic, social grouping where members align around a shared purpose (or multiple overlapping purposes) and participate in a shared culture. Active community participation frequently aligns with a sense of belonging and affiliation to the community. In a community the flow of information is multi-directional with members able to do something as a result of being connected to one another that they would not be able to do alone.”
Community: shared purpose, belonging, culture

I think before going further its worth defining what a community is and this quote from the Center for Scientific Collaboration and Community Engagement gives a clear definition.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
What are Communities? (cont.)
 The Turing Way - Communities DOI : 10.5281/zenodo.3695300





Nurturing a community within Sheffield and as part of the wider International community…

Brings together people with shared goals.
Gives them a sense of belonging.
Allows people to make connections
This gives them opportunities to learn and grow.

…all of which encourages and enables people to take action, adopting Open Science practices, normalising practices and achieving more than they might have on their own.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Open Science Tools



https://101innovations.wordpress.com/



As I’m sure most of you are aware, there are a lot of tools out there these days for undertaking open research, sometimes it can be a little overwhelming.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Diffusion of Innovation


When any innovative technology or practice comes along you will typically encounter this sort of pattern of diffusion where there are a few innovators who develop the system, slightly more early adopters will pick things up soon after, and following them there is the early majority where uptake increases dramatically. Unfortunately there is still a large proportion of people who have a propensity to resist change, some have low resistance, termed here the late majority, some with higher resilience, somewhat unflatteringly termed the laggards.
By normalising open research practices through building of an active community we accelerate and lower the bar to adoption of practices and reach the early and late majority and the stragglers faster.
And I don’t think its about making massive leaps

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Connecting People

Range of career stages and skills/knowledge/experience.
Support beyond training courses.
Sharing knowledge between researchers to learn from each other.


When one person teaches, two people learn.

The University comprises a range of researchers in terms of career stages, early, mid and advanced and across each of these there is variation in the skills, knowledge and experience around the different areas of Open Science, some people have experience in publishing pre-registering study protocols, others in publishing data on Sheffield ORDA, yet others such as myself have familiarity with the FAIR Principles for data sharing whilst others are familiar with FAIR for Research Software and applying them to publishing open source software projects.
Training courses are great for getting started but typically when applying what you’ve learned to your own domain/work/situation there will be questions and problems that crop up and this is where the support of a community comes in really helpful as you have a network of people you can contact and ask for help.
Sharing this knowledge directly between researchers so they learn from each other is a highly effective means of normalising the practices because…when one person teaches two people learn.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
The Power of Peer-to-Peer

Less intimidating
Experience > Expertise
Practical > Theoretical
Specificity
Participation is the key


Peer-to-peer teaching can be far less intimidating than formal teaching environments and it lowers the threshold for asking for help when it is felt that the community is supportive and encouraging.
Very often experience is more important than expertise. From my own experience knowing a system really well means that you can often overlook certain aspects that you take for granted and that someone new to a system might struggle to understand or use.
In a similar vein sharing practical experience of how to use tools is often more beneficial than deep theoretical explanations. There can often be many aspects that might be covered in theoretical material that aren’t relevant to someone getting started and only come into play further down the line.
In the same vein the more specific a topic is the better, it ensures that the necessary detail is covered and that it is relevant to those attending which improves engagement.



The key to a successful community really is about participation though and peer-to-peer interactions help promote this.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Structure

Core Team of active members, inclusive and diverse.
Independent, bottom-up, self-governing, self-steering.
Not determined by institutional policies.
Collaborate with institutional Open Research programmes…

Library
FAIR Roadmap Working Group
Reproducibilitea
Data Visualisation Hub

All staff, researchers, support staff and administrators.


The structure of the Open Scholarship Community consists of a core team of active members which should be inclusive and diverse, with members from all faculties represented. Members in specific domains are better positioned to engage with and inspire their peers. It is important to have representatives from all faculties to encourage wide-spread adoption and avoid any one group from feeling excluded or that Open Scholarship isn’t for them.
The community is meant to be an independent, bottom-up, self-governing and self-steering group, not determined by institutional policies but should cooperate with the existing structures for Open Research, library efforts and so forth and should work with existing groups such as the FAIR Roadmap Working Group, Reproucibilitea and the Data Visualisation hub to name but a few.
Its aimed at all staff, not just researchers but support staff and administrators.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Open Research Conversations
Drop-in sessions
Sheffield ReproducibiliTea
Sheffield R User Groups . . . .
Your Ideas


 



There are already a number of community activities in Sheffield. Jenni Adams, the library Open Research Manager and organised or OpenFest2023, organises the monthly Open Research Conversations which are lunchtime seminars open to all where typically two speakers discuss particular issues in open research followed by discussion.
Adam Partridge runs monthly drop-in sessions for those engaged in and interested in Open Research to discuss topics.
In the past Zuzzana XXX and Jim Uttley have organised local Reproducibilitea Journal Clubs where specific research articles covering Open Research practices or examples of papers where such practices have been used were run. These tailed off around the pandemic but we will be rejuvenating them.
Similarly there used to be the Sheffield R User Group which met to showcase using the R statistical software and associated ecosystem for undertaking reproducible research. The frequency of these meetings varied but again tailed off and haven’t been run. Myself and Grace Accad of the Data Visualisation and Analysis Team are getting these back up and running with a relaunch scheduled for October. We’d be keen to hear from you if you use R and have some work you would like to present, but we’ll have regular slots on using Quarto for different aspects of open research.
Most importantly though the community is shaped by you, if you’ve an interest or need to know more about a particualr subject please come and join the community. If you’ve material on Open Research practices, whether that is pre-registration, making your data Open and FAIR, reproducible writing, using the Open Science Framework or anything that you might have shared with colleagues within your team or department please consider sharing it with the wider community within the University. The communities activities and direction are meant to be guided by its members so please get involved.
